Which till they be, they badly brooke delayes,
And on that wiſhed day agree'd they are,
The interpoſed time they count by dayes,
Not yeares, nor months, for t'will not reach ſo farre,
Soone were they wed, their ioyes the want ſupplide
Of meet ſolemnitie that haſt denide.
Heauen vpon earth ſeemes to his ſhare to fall,
That doth enioy a fayre, kind, vertuous wife:
He that hath one that fayles herein, in all,
He ſeemes to be in hell euen in this life.
Prince Curans hap doth match the beſt of theſe,
So exquiſitly well his choyce doth pleaſe.
She is adorn'd, ſhe is indude likewiſe
With the beſt gifts of body, and of mind:
And (whence much comfort doth to him ariſe)
Shee's ſober, chaſt, ſtill, tractable and kind:
Not ſuch a one as women are is ſhe,
But ſhe is ſuch a one as they ſhould be.
Shee doth not (for ſhe knowes ſhe ſhould not doo't)
Beare wilfull ſway as they that headſhip ſhare:
So that oftimes the head is made the foot.
But they that beare this, too baſe minded are.
Shall men be made their humours ſlaues, when they
Were made for men, and were inioyn'd t'obey.
A louely ſweet Companion hath he got,
Which heauen in loue did vpon him beſtow,
Now happineſſe is falue vnto his lot,
If happineſſe a man may haue below.
For tis a hap beings happineſſe with it,
To happen on a ch • yce in all things fit.
He that would be ſo bleſt, and ſo reioyce,
Muſt heed, and good aduiſe (in chooſing) take,
As well, or ill; a man doth make his choyce,
Better, or worſe, his fortune he doth make.
Nay, (which is more) the man that wiſely wiues,
Much good to his poſterity deriues.
If ſhe be fayre, and of a comely ſeature,
May not her like be then on her imprinted:
And if ſhe be a kind good natur'd creature,
Shee's not ſo to her ſelfe confin'd and ſtinted:
But that the branch that ſprings from ſuch a tree,
May beare like fruit, and of like nature be.
If ſhee haue more then Nature can conuay,
Good quallities by education got:
They are communicable, and ſhe may
Confer them on her Iſſue (may ſhe not?)
Then he that makes good choyce deriues thereby
Good to himſelfe and his poſteritie.
If ſhe with goodnes be indu'de and grace,
Why then (with her) doth ſhe Heauens bleſſing bring.
And he within whoſe boſome theſe haue place,
Will more make theſe his ayme then any thing.
Theſe and what elſe may breede his bliſſe beſide,
Are the Endowments of Prince Curans Bride.
And now though he till now had liu'd obſcure,
Loſtin Loues Labrinth, doting ſo vpon her:
Now that he hath her in poſſeſſion ſure,
His vallour now redeems his morgadg'd honor.
For Fiery quallitie from Mars hee tooke.
Though ſhe could daunt him with an angrie looke.
What could he doo, while he wore Beautyes Gyues?
What could he do, while he Loues Priſoner was?
He could not, did not then, but now he ſtriues,
Euen Hercules in valour to ſurpaſſe.
A brauer Knight, liu'd not in any Land,
For Courage, Skill in Armes, and ſtrength of hand.
Elſe-where he warr'd, and wonne, ere claim'd his right,
Of Edell, in behalfe of Argentile:
(Deny'de of it) hee vowes in bloudy fight,
To winne the ſame, if Fortune on him ſmile.
If not, for what ſhall happe, prepar'de is hee,
Braue mindes for Fortunes both, reſolued be.
An Armie ſoone (though ſmall) he had prepar'd,
(By him exampled) bold and guided well,
And with the ſame on Edell falſe be war'd,
Beneath his ſword on heapes his foe-men fell,
Who (trembling) think hee's Mars himſelf, & wonder,
At his great ſtrokes, which kill like ſtroke of thunder.
He rides amongſt the thickeſt of his foes,
And deales his almes about on euery ſide,
So ſetting bloud abroach ſtill as he goes,
That purple ſtreames along the field did glide,
As oft as his vplifted ſword deſcends,
So oft a ſoule he to Elizian ſends.
So many bodyes he depriu'd of breath,
That weary waxed his victorious arme,
While tugging Caron almoſt toyl'd to death,
Tranſports the Ghoſts to'th' Stigion banks that ſwarm:
And ſtill as faſt as Caron waftes them ore,
Prince Curans conquering blade vnbodieth more.
To ward his blowes, their bucklers are too thinne,
So are their armours to defend their fides,
Not walls of yron ſecure their liues within,
Through ſhield and ſhirt of male his Fauchion glides,
Expelling from thoſe houſes fraile of clay,
Thoſe fayre immortall gueſts that there did ſtay.
So pearcing were the puſhes of his ſpeare,
So ſharpe his thruſts, ſo ponderous his blowes,
That his ſtrong foes though ten for one they were,
Like to a ſtreame or ſtorme he ouerthrowes.
For as a Lyon teares a tender Kid,
So (vndermatcht) euen what he would he did.
There was no ſtrength that Curans ſtrength withſtood,
He lops their armes, or elſe their heads he cleft,
And ſo he paſſeth on imbru'd with bloud,
The field behind all ſtrew'd with corps he left,
A Gyant then ſuborn'd to Edels ayde,
Oppoſ'd the Prince, his bloudy progreſſe ſtayde.
Huge, ſterne this Gyant was, and paſſing proud,
And ſcornd the Prince as much his vndermatch,
And his baſe voyce he lifting vp aloud,
Cries here he comes, that will thee ſoone diſpatch:
But his proud brags could not Prince Curan ſeare,
They rather to his courage wheſtones were.
Looke how thoſe vapors meet that out are blowne,
From two huge Cannons, mouth to mouth oppoſ'd,
The meeting of theſe Warriors ſuch was knowne,
Such their incounter was, and ſo they cloſ'd,
Long (to confound the Prince) the Gyant ſtriues,
But failes, for Curan him of life depriues.
(He dead) the reſt betakes themſelues to flight,
And time it is for he that ſtayes he dyes:
Yet Edell diſcontinued not the fight,
So loath was he to looſe his dignities.
Nor would he ceaſe till him Prince Curan ſlue,
And payde the debt that long before was due.
Mercy was offered, he did it deſpiſe,
And at the Prince with eager ſury ſmit,
Iuſt angers flames ſhin'd then in Curans eyes:
To ſurie, ruth, mercy to rage ſubmit.
With that he ſtrikes, nor need he ſtrike againe,
That ſtroke gaue end to Edels life and raigne.
This done, vpon the Crowne Prince Curan ſeaſ'd,
A pleaſing purchaſe though with perill bought,
Nor durſt the people ſhew themſelues but pleaſ'd,
They him applaud, and preſents to him brought,
The Nobles too, preſent their loues cachone,
And by thoſe ſteps, he mounts the kingly throne.
Curan and Argentile now crowned are,
She fayre, wiſe, vertuous, thence her prayſes roſe,
He graue and iuſt, a thunderbolt in war,
A Lambe, a Lyon, to his friendes and foes,
Northumber's crowne vndiuidable now,
Euen till his death adorn'd his kingly brow.

div.head: Faults eſcaped.
div.p: In the letter B. page 3. line 11, for beene fame, read being ſame. In C. pag. 5. line 3. for more powerfull, reade were powerfull. In C. pag. 7. line 12, for him runs, read it runs, In G. pag. 3. line 16. for our ſelues, reade our ſexe.
